moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6: Philidor's Defense, so called because the great Frenchman never actually played it. Black must play very exactly to avoid being swamped early.
moves.3... Bg4: A very risky line. Black's normal procedure in this defense is to close the game and play a solid, passive strategy.
moves.4... Bxf3: Black must do this before recapturing the Pawn [4...PxP? 5 QxQ ch KxQ 6 NxP wins a Pawn.]
moves.5. Qxf3: The Queen is now bearing on the very weak KB7 square.
moves.6. Bc4: Bearing down on KB7, and Black no longer has the option of ... P-Q4 to block the Bishop's diagonal.
moves.6... f6: Trying desperately to shut off White's attack.
moves.7. Qb3: Doubling on the diagonal and also threatening 8 QxNP winning a piece.
moves.8... Kd7: Black can choose the location of his death. If 8... K-K2, 9 Q-K6 mate. If, as played, 8... K-Q2 --
moves.9. Qe6#: -- also Q-K6 mate! Well played by Schmid.
